newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea unveils major securities liberalisation.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea unveils major securities liberalisation.

text.p: South Korea announced sweeping reforms of its securities market on Thursday, including the abolition of quotas on new stock issues.
Quotas on initial public offerings (IPOs) will be scrapped on September 1, according to a statement by the Ministry of Finance and Economy.
The package adopts many of the proposals recommended by the Korea Securities Research Institute in July.

From September 1, the government will also lift controls on capital increases by local firms and financial institutions. But it will maintain the current level of control over state-run corporations when they are privatised.

Requirements for IPOs and capital increases will also be tightened from this date. All companies seeking to list or increase their capital will be required to have more than a 50 percent return on paid-in capital over three years, an asset value of more than 15,000 won ($18.3) per share and earnings per share (EPS) of more than 10,000 won.
The current standard is a 30 percent return on capital, an asset value of 7,500 won per share, and EPS of 5,000 won.
Large companies which paid an average dividend of 400 won or more per share over the past three years, will be free to increase their share capital.
Smaller firms will be required to pay an average dividend of 300 won per share, a ministry official said.
Issuing companies must disclose their future dividend policy at the time of new stock issues.
To liberalise the pricing of IPO issues, the government said it would remove the mandatory pricing guidelines set by the Securities Exchange Commission, effective September 1.
In an effort to prevent the dominance of equity financing by the nation's large conglomerates, the government will impose limits on the nation's top 10 conglomerates.
The Korea Stock Exchange currently stipulates that investors deposit securities and cash equal to 40 percent of the value of stock they want to buy.
Margin trading in stocks on the second tier of the bourse will be also allowed from September 1.
The government will permit home trading from personal computers from the first half of next year, allowing investors to place and receive confirmation of orders through their terminals.
Some rules require a revision of the Securities Exchange Law and the government will submit the necessary amendments to parliament in October.

From September 1, annual capital increases by a company affiliated with one of the top 10 conglomerates will be restricted to four percent of the total outstanding value of the stock or 100 billion won, whichever is larger.
The daily share price fluctuation limit will be expanded to eight percent from November and to 10 percent in the first half of 1997, compared with six percent currently.
From September 1, securities houses will be allowed to set their own margin requirements for stock purchases, the ministry official said.
